Award.AwardTitle: Solvation and structure for systems with strong Coulomb interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
John D. Weeks of the University of Maryland, College Park, is supported by an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to carry out theoretical research on solvation in dielectric fluids like water and in charged ionic fluids as well. The principal investigator and coworkers have developed a new local molecular field (LMF) theory that relates the structure of a nonuniform system with long-ranged Coulomb interactions in an arbitrary external field to that of a simpler "mimic system" with short ranged interactions but in an effective or renormalized field that accounts for the averaged effects of the long ranged interactions. The external field can represent the interaction of the solvent with a fixed, arbitrarily complicated, and possibly charged solute, and the solvation free energy is determined as the field is gradually turned on. The solvation process in the short ranged mimic system avoids computationally expensive methods used in conventional treatments of Coulomb interactions and a very simple and analytic expression for the difference in solvation free energy between the full and mimic systems has been derived. LMF theory gives exceptionally accurate results for solvation of simple spherical models of hydrophobic and hydrophilic solutes of varying sizes in water, the most important solvent. Ongoing research will focus on theoretical generalizations of these ideas, along with applications to more complex solvation problems of interest in biophysics and materials science.

An accurate determination of free energy changes during solvation is required for a quantitative understanding of a vast array of chemical and biophysical processes in solution, ranging from protein folding to drug partitioning across cell membranes. The new solvation theory developed by the investigator and coworkers is simple, physically motivated, and very accurate, so the results of this research should be accessible to experimentalists and theorists with diverse backgrounds and may provide a common language for work in overlapping areas of chemistry, physics, and biology. The research in this proposal contributes directly to the interdisciplinary training of graduate students and postdocs, who gain experience in a unique combination of analytical thinking, numerical solutions of newly derived equations, and computer simulations using both in house programs and state of the art simulation packages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this grant period we introduced a new theory for solvation thermodynamics in dielectric fluids like water and in charged ionic fluids as well. Thermodynamic quantities like the solvation free energy determine many important physical properties, e.g., how readily different molecules or ions (solutes) dissolve in water. In previous NSF supported work, we developed a new, and very accurate approach called local molecular field (LMF) theory. LMF theory introduces a general mapping that relates the structure (arrangements of molecules) of a nonuniform fluid with long ranged intermolecular interactions in an arbitrary external field (representing say confining walls or fixed solutes) to that of a simpler "mimic system" with short ranged interactions but in an effective field accounting for the averaged effects of the long ranged interactions.

To determine solvation free energies the  field can represent the interaction of the full water solvent with a complicated and possibly charged solute or biopolymer. In principle we can then use computer simulations to determine the change in solvation free energy and other thermodynamic properties as the water-solute field is turned on. However using standard methods these simulations are computationally very costly because of the long range of the Coulomb interactions betweens the charges and dipoles in the solute and in the  water solvent, since interactions even from distant charges must then be accounted for. However, the analogous solvation free energy in the short ranged mimic system can be determined much more easily with no such computational overhead. 

In our new theoretical work we derived a very simple and analytic expression for the difference in solvation free energy between the full and mimic systems. This yields a general method for determining very accurate solvation free energies.  We demonstrated the utility of our approach by examining three very different and challenging problems:  i) the hydration thermodynamics of uncharged hydrophobic ion cores;  ii) solvation of charged cores representing ionic solutes;  iii) the solvation of a large, highly charged colloid that exhibits overcharging, a complex nonlinear electrostatic phenomenon whereby counterions from the solvent effectively overscreen and locally invert the integrated charge of the solvated object. Quantitative results from our theory are found in all cases.

LMF theory presents a general conceptual framework that gives qualitative as well as quantitative insight into many other problems as well. Here we discuss two such applications based on work carried out during current NSF funding.

1) Hydrophobicity Scaling of Aqueous Interfaces by an Electrostatic Mapping
An understanding of the relative hydrophobicity of complex heterogeneous molecular assemblies is crucial to characterize and predict interactions between biomolecules and for processes vital to life like protein folding. Recently much progress has been made by looking at fluctuations of the adjacent water layer around solutes, which are strongly affected by the nature of the underlying surface. However measuring such fluctuations require choice of an appropriate probe volume and can be computationally very costly.

Here we used LMF theory to introduce a novel electrostatics-based mapping of aqueous interfaces that focuses on the collective, large scale electrostatic response of water to the presence of nearby surfaces. This equilibrium calculation is generally much easier to carry out for complex surfaces or biomolecules than the fluctuation based methods and can readily distinguish between hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions. Moreover this electrostatic mapping can also differentiate between different hydrophilic regions that polarize nearby waters in opposing directions, something the fluctuation based scales cannot do. In general we believe that both hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions play an important role in molecular assembly and our new theory allows for a general treatment of both interactions.

2) Role of Local Response in Ion Solvation: Born Theory and Beyond
A major landmark in the theoretical description of ion solvation was the model developed by Born in 1920. While this model sometimes yields estimates of solvation thermodynamic quantities in reasonable order of magnitude agreement with experiment, it completely fails to capture the experimentally observed asymmetry of ion solvation free energies with respect to the sign (positive or negative) of the ion charge.

In new theoretical work we examined the microscopic origins of the ionic charge asymmetry. We first derived an exact expression for the charging component of the ionic free energy, the free energy change when the Coulomb interactions between a fixed ion and the solvent are gradually “turned on”. Using LMF ideas, we then gave a new and simple physical derivation of the Born model. We show that the Born model linearly and locally relates the induced solvent charge density to that of the applied ionic charge. This enables the study of a new thermodynamic cycle for the solvation free energy with a charge-symmetric first step well-described by the Born model. The charge asymmetric contributions can then be quantitatively examined in the remaining steps of the cycle.
